intro: Oxytropis melanotricha, commonly known as black-haired locoweed, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the western United States and parts of Canada. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, also known as the legume or pea family, and is characterized by its compound leaves and small, pea-like flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky or sandy soils and is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments. Its root system is deep and extensive, allowing it to access moisture from lower soil layers. Oxytropis melanotricha is also known for its toxic properties, containing alkaloids that can be harmful to livestock.
